p: Banna virus (BAV), which belongs to the species Banna virus of the genus Seadornavirus within the family Reoviridae, was first isolated in mainland China in 1987 from a patient with meningoencephalitis ( 198, 199). Since then, BAV has been obtained from pigs, cattle, ticks, mosquitoes, and Culicoides biting midges over a wide range of mainland China ( 200, 201). The virus is thought to cause encephalitis in humans, and many cases associated with it might have been misdiagnosed as Japanese encephalitis ( 200). At present, there is no evidence of a relationship between BAV and ruminant illness.
